channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Yuki Iwamura/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler/Reuters
item.media:description: A health care worker in protective gear treated a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last month.

item.title: Trump Administration Revives Banned Hunting Techniques in Alaska
item.description: The move reverses an Obama-era ban on hunting methods like baiting bears with doughnuts and shooting swimming caribou.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: David Tipling/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A brown bear and her cub in Katmai National Park in southern Alaska.

item.title: Two Men Are Accused of Posing as New York Police Officers in Armed Robbery
item.description: Prosecutors said that the men, wearing bulletproof vests, medical masks and gloves, robbed a Manhattan jewelry store of $150,000 in valuables.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Julio Cortez/Associated Press

item.title: Warren Kanders Says He Is Getting Out of the Tear Gas Business
item.description: Amid protests in which his company’s products have been used by the police, the ex-Whitney Museum trustee said that the company, Safariland, would sell off its crowd-control products divisions.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Andrew White for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the Whitney Museum in May of last year, when they demanded that Warren Kanders be removed from the museum’s board of trustees.

item.title: Evoking History, Black Cowboys Take to the Streets
item.description: The presence of black cowboys and cowgirls at protests is a reclaiming of the traditional role of mounted riders in demonstrations in urban communities.
item.dc:creator: Walter Thompson-Hernández and Kayla Reefer
item.media:credit: Kayla Reefer for The New York Times

item.title: What It Looks Like Inside an Amazon Warehouse Now
item.description: Amazon, which has been under fire on worker safety, invited us into one facility to show its response.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise and Ruth Fremson

item.title: A Museum Canceled a Show About Police Brutality. Now It Has Regrets.
item.description: MoCA Cleveland has apologized to the artist Shaun Leonardo, whose charcoal drawings represent victims of police violence.
item.dc:creator: Brian Boucher
item.media:credit: Lelanie Foster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Leonardo wrote that “institutional white fragility led to an act of censorship.”

item.title: Major Problems With Voting in Atlanta as 5 States Hold Primaries
item.description: Some voting machines were not working as polls opened, and voters across Georgia reported long lines and widespread frustration. Nevada, North Dakota, South Carolina and West Virginia are also voting today.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poll worker allowed people in to vote at Central Park Recreation Center in Atlanta on Tuesday.

item.title: What to Know About Calls to Defund the Police in California
item.description: Tuesday: Here’s what to know about the demands to defund and dismantle police departments. Also: An update on reopening.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Ringo H.W. Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Hollywood on June 2.

item.title: Pandemic Threatens to Upend a Thriving Real Estate Model
item.description: Safety concerns have forced developers to rethink mixed-use projects combining retail, residences and offices, which have helped define the live-work-play ethos that many younger professionals seek.
item.dc:creator: Tom Acitelli
item.media:credit: Mark Wickens for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 28-acre Hudson Yards complex, the largest mixed-use project in the country, according to CoStar, brought new life to an underused corner of Manhattan.

item.title: A Movement Meets a Question: Defund or Reform the Police?
item.description: A movement arrives at a key question, and Joe Biden takes a side: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: The ‘Defund’ Conundrum
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mural on 16th St. near the White House in Washington.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Updates
item.description: Seven million people have been infected worldwide, and new cases globally hit a high on Sunday, according to the W.H.O. Central banks are seeking new tools to offset the downturn.
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in São Paulo, Brazil. The country has the second-highest number of confirmed coronavirus cases, behind only the United States.

item.title: Wall Street Retreats After Monday’s Rally: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Steve Sisney/Reuters
item.media:description: Chesapeake Energy warned in a securities filing last month that it may reorganize under bankruptcy protection.

item.title: A Small Mississippi Town, ‘Asking for a Breath’ After Mayor’s Remarks Unleash Protests
item.description: Protests over George Floyd’s death have reached small towns like Petal, Miss., a predominantly white community where neighbors are confronting one another and talking about racial divides.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: L. Kasimu Harris for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered outside the City Hall of Petal, Miss.

item.title: Testing Nursing Home Workers Can Help Stop Coronavirus. But Who Should Pay?
item.description: A patchwork of state and U.S. recommendations has hampered efforts to devise a uniform policy, leading to disputes over whether insurers or employers should cover testing costs.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Katie Orlinsky for The New York Times

item.title: Watch Live: George Floyd Funeral in Houston Today
item.description: The death of George Floyd galvanized a movement, as cities from New York to Los Angeles consider changes to police funding. Loved ones are remembering him as a man who wanted to “touch the world.”
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times

item.title: George Floyd, From ‘I Want to Touch the World’ to ‘I Can’t Breathe’
item.description: Mr. Floyd had big plans for life nearly 30 years ago. His death in police custody is powering a movement against police brutality and racial injustice.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial to George Floyd in Minneapolis.

item.title: Georgia Primary Election: Is This the Year Georgia Flips?
item.description: With both Senate seats in play and President Trump up for re-election in November, Georgia Democrats are telling anyone who will listen: This time, it’s real.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jon Ossoff waited in line to vote last week in Atlanta. Mr. Ossoff, a Democrat who lost a special election for a House seat in 2017, is running for the Senate.

item.title: Texas Inmate Who Spent Nearly 40 Years on Death Row Is Granted Parole
item.description: Bobby Moore, 60, had been the center of a landmark case in which the U.S. Supreme Court overturned his death sentence because he is intellectually disabled.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Contradicting Trump, Barr Says Bunker Visit Was for Safety, Not an ‘Inspection’
item.description: The attorney general’s account stood in direct contrast to the version that the president offered last week when he suggested he had merely been looking the place over.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr during a round-table event with President Trump and law enforcement officials on Monday at the White House.

item.title: Police Officer Shared Nude Photos of Student Before She Was Murdered, Lawsuit Says
item.description: The parents of Lauren McCluskey contend that a campus police officer disseminated explicit images of the University of Utah student that had been used by her killer to blackmail her.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Rajah Bose for The New York Times
item.media:description: Artwork of Lauren McCluskey in her room at her parents’ home, where she grew up, in Pullman, Wash.

item.title: After Protests, Politicians Reconsider Police Budgets and Discipline
item.description: Elected officials are exploring changes ranging from defunding police departments to requiring more accountability.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey, John Eligon and Farah Stockman
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Washington painted the phrase “defund the police” onto 16th Street on Saturday night.

item.title: Trump Rebuffs Protests Over Systemic Racism and Calls Police ‘Great People’
item.description: In a meeting with law enforcement officials, Mr. Trump said he opposed any defunding or dismantling of police departments, which many demonstrators have been demanding to address police violence.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: “There won’t be defunding. There won’t be dismantling of our police,” President Trump said during a round table with law enforcement officials on Monday at the White House.

item.title: #PublishingPaidMe and a Day of Action Reveal an Industry Reckoning
item.description: A viral hashtag encouraged black and nonblack book authors to compare their pay. Publishers pledged to improve their diversity efforts.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León and Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:credit: Marla Aufmuth/Getty Images
item.media:description: The novelist Jesmyn Ward said that she “fought and fought” for a six-figure advance even after she won the first of two National Book Awards.

item.title: Astronaut Kathy Sullivan Becomes First Woman to Reach Challenger Deep
item.description: The astronaut Kathy Sullivan, 68, is now also the first woman to reach the Challenger Deep, about seven miles below the ocean’s surface.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Enrique Alvarez
item.media:description: Kathy Sullivan and Victor Vescovo after their 35,810-foot dive to the Challenger Deep.

item.title: Why Joe Biden Is in Good Shape (for Now)
item.description: His poll numbers look good. His opponent’s strategy seems disjointed. (But also, it’s June.)
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: In Houston, Thousands Wait in the Heat to Pay Respects to George Floyd
item.description: People lined up for hours to view the body of a man who died in police custody in Minneapolis — a man who was one of them in so many ways.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners arriving for a memorial of George Floyd at the Fountain of Praise church in Houston on Monday.

item.title: Senate Moves Toward Preserving Public Lands, and Political Careers
item.description: Despite some resistance within their ranks, Republicans are pushing a popular public lands bill that could help endangered colleagues, with an eye toward protecting their majority in November.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: “I was going to get this done come hell or high water,” said Senator Cory Gardner, Republican of Colorado.

item.title: Despite Recession, Stock Markets Turn Positive for the Year
item.description: The S&P 500 climbed back above where it began the year on the same day that economists said the United States fell into a recession in February.
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips

item.title: CrossFit Gyms Meets Black Lives Matter
item.description: CrossFit inspires extreme devotion. Now it’s repelling sponsors and gym affiliates and alienating its community.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman and Lauren Hard

item.title: The Travel Business is Picking Up for Summer
item.description: After months of staying at home during the pandemic, Americans are heading to vacation destinations like Florida and national parks.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fontainebleau Miami Beach, a resort that had closed because of the coronavirus pandemic, is enjoying brisk business since it reopened on June 1.

item.title: Man Who Drove Into Protesters Said He Was a K.K.K. Leader, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Harry H. Rogers drove into a group of demonstrators near Richmond, Va., on Sunday, the authorities said. The county prosecutor called him “an admitted leader of the Ku Klux Klan.”
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Henrico County Police
item.media:description: It was unclear whether Harry H. Rogers’s claims about his membership in the Ku Klux Klan were true. He is currently being held without bond.

item.title: How to Feed Crowds in a Protest or Pandemic? The Sikhs Know
item.description: Their centuries-old faith tradition of nourishing anyone in need has found new energy and purpose in America’s turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Ryan Christopher Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Queens Village group fed people last week at a Sunnyside protest over the killing of George Floyd and other black Americans by the police.

item.title: Biden Pours Millions Into Facebook Ads, Blowing Past Trump’s Record
item.description: Joe Biden spent $1.6 million on Facebook last Thursday as his campaign capitalized on energy surrounding mass protests. That’s far more than President Trump has spent on the platform on a single day.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden campaign’s biggest online advertising blitz of the 2020 race has gathered contact information from more than 1.2 million people, a valuable collection of potential donors.

item.title: Democrats Unveil Sweeping Police Reform Bill
item.description: The measure, the most expansive intervention into policing that lawmakers have proposed in recent memory, is likely to draw opposition from Republicans and police unions.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other Democratic leaders commemorated the lives of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor and Ahmaud Arbery in the Capitol on Monday.
